column5: What is the purpose of your club?
column6: What are some activities that take place during a typical meeting?
column7: What best describes the role of your club?
column11: Please upload a photo for the front page of the website

column5: The purpose of this club is to allow both beginner and experienced programmers to get together once a week to share ideas and learn. The main focus of the club is to teach beginners how to code, but there will also be more advanced teachings offered to people that already have some coding knowledge. Some examples would be: tutoring for AP Computer Science A, as well as setting teams up for Hackathons.
column6: Members of the club get together at lunchtime each Tuesday at the designated meeting room. Some executives will be in charge of teaching general lessons for everyone, while others may be helping with more advanced topics, or helping newcomers that are new to the club.
column7: Academic: Your club acts to help students on their academic journey.
column17: A programming environment welcoming people of all skill levels.

column5: Service based club which helps out in the school and the community at large. Work actively with Lion's Club of Canada outside of school and on projects within the school.
column6: At meetings, we discuss upcoming events, fundraisers and ways to get involved.  Students also meet to help each other with a variety of activities from resume building, to interview skills to mentorship.  Also have guests come and talk to the group at large on opportunities for community service or ways to support different causes.
column9: Lunchtime;Sometimes after school for special events

column5: At BC Children’s Hospital Club we contribute our fullest abilities to create inspiring and creative fundraising events. Our initiatives connect and inform students about raising awareness and donations for the children and families in need. Students also come together to practice leadership skills and responsibilities, while expanding their personal interests and passion.
column6: Class brainstorming sessions, separate executive meetings, club games and activities, poster painting and etc.

column5: To create and prepare teams to participate in the Reach for the Top trivia competition.
column6: Practice trivia games, coaching.

column5: To celebrate the diversity of cultures at FH to instill positive personal & cultural identity
column6: Planning for acknowledging global holidays and activities at FH

column5: Volunteering in the school & community
column6: Planning for our Weekly litter pickups afterschool Thursday, bases buddies, and helping senior citizens

column5: To provide a space for LGBTQ community and allies to plan and discuss inclusivity
column6: Plan for pride events and important days

column5: To represent the Fraser Heights creative community in monthly newspaper issues, giving students the opportunity to share their voices and keep informed on things going on around the community.
column6: Brainstorming ideas, assigning editors/layout artists, discussing suggestions, etc.

column5: To build a community of gamers that can be free and have a comfortable place to be in.
column6: Socializing, watching gaming events, playing video games

column5: The International Ambassador Club is dedicated to promoting cultural understanding and equality amongst our large International Student population at Fraser Heights Secondary. The International Ambassador’s hold monthly meetings and accept all students in its membership. The Ambassador’s work with new and returning International Students to develop community and a sense of belonging in our school and in the community at large. The International Ambassador Club is an avenue to foster strong relationships with peers and staff and share in cultural celebrations.
column6: Create a space for belonging and connectedness amongst students (ELL and International) Host new student orientations. Create resources, events and opportunities to support new Fraser Heights Firehawks (such as YouTube videos that help new students in their first language to sign up for lockers, access MyEd, download the app, etc.). Host International Lunches, cultural events and holidays.

column5:
1. To build a community of enthusiastic programmers that help each other
2. To teach beginners the basics of programming, so that some of them would build a passion or interest in programming
3. To have fun by coding, by giving out candies and hosting events like kahoots, competitions, game jams, etc.
4. To provide help with events like AP Computer Science and CCC
column6:
Normally, we would split into two small groups, junior (no experience ~ beginner) and senior (more experienced). Juniors will
learn the basics of programming using Java, and seniors will be given some challenges or projects to do. And for both groups, free
candies if you do something correctly! All throughout the meeting execs will be available for help. 
We have bi-monthly coding competitions with awards, as well as other events.

column5: To educate students on legal proceedings, while practicing public speaking by preparing mock cases.
column6: Lessons and drills on mock trial speaking positions, official mock trials (including inter-club tournaments, and possible provincial-held tournaments), tournament preparation for members competing in official mock trials, and fun speech practices with impromptu topics.

column5: To teach students and help them improve their speaking skills in debate on all levels.
column6: In every meeting, the club engages its members on a variety of different activities from lessons to full on debates to help them critically expand their debating abilities and argumentation.

column5: To provide friendly dance lessons to people of all levels
column6: Dance Lessons, Games, etc.

column4: Mrs. Brar, Ms. Gonsales, Ms. Wong
column5: We create a space that allows students to have a chance to lead and collaborate to further build a positive school environment and culture. We promote positive school activities and host fun spirit events! We promote spirit within the school.
column6: Every week theres something new! We brainstorm, plan, and organize school spirit events. We work as a team to create a fun and enthusiastic school environment by sharing ideas with with the team. We turn ideas into actions!

column5: Homework club is run by a group of Fraser Heights Students who are eager to help out students in various subjects. This club is great for students who'd like extra help on assignments from a knowledgeable peer. It’s a welcoming and warm environment that’s enjoyable for students.
column6: Students create posters, discuss how to spread the word about the club, and most importantly assist peers with their assignments

column5: To obtain a sustainable lifestyle and combat climate change through individual actions.
column6: Battery challenge, pens and markers collection, litter pickups

column5: Holding competitive and collaborative team discussions where students analyze, criticize, and compare ethical dilemmas. This provides students the opportunity to think critically, apply their knowledge in the real world, and deepen their awareness of ethical values.
column6: In a typical Ethics Bowl meeting, students discuss and analyze case studies that involve political, social, or economic dilemmas. Students practice their public speaking and critical thinking skills by splitting up into two teams and proposing solutions to ethical issues. Coaches also train students on philosophical perspectives and speaking strategies, preparing them for upcoming competitions

column5: To provide a social, informative, and fun environment for students to learn and play the game of chess and compete in spirited competitions.
column6: During a typical meeting, we may watch videos on new chess openings and tactics, have mini in-class tournaments, or just play with our peers.

column5: To spread awareness on current events and global issues while advocating for people in need through fundraisers and humanitarian aid.
column6:
- Current events presentations
- Fundraiser logistics planning
- Initiative brainstorming/execution

column5: To plan and prepare for Robotics competitions in the Surrey Robotics League
column6: In meetings we plan for competitions, and delegate tasks. We are currently at capacity, so please see Mrs Desrochers to put your name on the waitlist.

column5: We are the Fraser Heights Youth for Care Club! A group of friendly people who are interested in nothing but giving back to our beautiful community.We are associated with the Surrey Memorial Hospital and the Surrey Memorial Hospital Foundation. We give back by fundraising for them, making care packages for the children staying in the hospital and we give our own members insight on the healthcare and medical field by bringing in healthcare professionals to do Doctor Talks!
column6: We are focused on helping the youth of our school and other people in any way we can through fundraising activities. We also are focused on the medicinal field and provide “doctor talks” to students in order to give them an insight into the real world and how there is a large variety of healthcare professionals. In their talks, they give you tips and tricks to follow in their footsteps and what to prepare for if you are interested in pursuing a career in the healthcare/medical field.

column5: The purpose of the FHSS Anime club is to promote and improve the communication skills between students of any grades using Japanese pop culture as a foundation, as well as the building of long lasting memories and connections. Society is built on social engagement, so we strive to increase the availability of such events.
column6: Weekly meetings are on Wednesdays from 3:00pm - 4:30pm. Each meeting will start by watching 2 or 3 episodes from an anime that the club members voted on at the beginning of each semester. After, we would play some games including; Jackbox, Garticphone, and other fun activities.
